intro: Phoradendron oblongifolium, commonly known as the mistletoe, is a parasitic plant that attaches itself to the branches of host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is native to various regions of the Americas. The plant produces small, white or yellowish berries that contain sticky seeds, which adhere to the bark of host trees. Its leaves are typically small, elliptical, and opposite in arrangement. Phoradendron oblongifolium plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food for birds and other animals.
